content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I liked this, was quite fun!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple et efficace

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash :) easy to understand
To check for lazy/incorrect matching, I would include tests with pairs of hobbies such as pets/crumpets, diving/skydiving, drawing/drawingpins

I think tests #2 and #3 can be combined into one test without issue.

Also, your output section should say "if there are multiple potential dates, pick the first one" rather than just "2 potential dates."
Will add more test cases (longer lists of hobbies)

a less geeky way of the same thing is to list the hobbies as strings instead of represented as bits - could add some variety to the puzzle, e.g.
Me fishing cycling reading 
2
Alice movies theatre reading crafts
Zena programming fishing baking restaurants

Maybe you could have added names to the puzzle, so a single line could be "Alice 123" (or Andy) and then output the name :-)
Usual syntax is "<<Next [[N]] lines:>>"
Why just 2^8 ? Why just 10 dates ?
You should say "If there are multiple potential dates, pick the first one"
You say 0 <= [[ME]] - but you never have a test with [[ME]] = 0 - I suggest change the constraint to 0 < [[ME]]
Please add "write answer" to your stub script.
All the best finding that date! :-)

Thanks for suggestions. The "hobbies stored as bits" was an idea I took from lessons with my students.

I've reworked it to be more human friendly

Updated description. I didn't update the #2 and #3 testcases, since 
#2 showcases "no hobbies" for potential date
#3 showcases "no simmilar hobbies" between me and potential date

Maybe it's not that necessary, but it might be helpful in "Reverse mode"
